titleStmt.title: The tvvo petitions of the Buckingham-shire men delivered the XIth of January one to the Peers, the other to the House of Commons, in the behalfe of Mr. Hampden, burgesse for their shire, &c. They being 4000. that came on horseback to deliver them. And also a relation of the free and voluntary offers of the trayned bands of the City of London; of the masters of shippes, mariners and seamen; of the aprentices of London; of the trayned bands of Southwarke, and of the watermen upon the Thames to defend the King and Parliament against malignant councells and plots of Papists.

titleStmt.title: The tvvo petitions of the Buckingham-shire men delivered the XIth of January one to the Peers, the other to the House of Commons, in the behalfe of Mr. Hampden, burgesse for their shire, &c. They being 4000. that came on horseback to deliver them. And also a relation of the free and voluntary offers of the trayned bands of the City of London; of the masters of shippes, mariners and seamen; of the aprentices of London; of the trayned bands of Southwarke, and of the watermen upon the Thames to defend the King and Parliament against malignant councells and plots of Papists.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TVVO PETITIONS OF THE BUCKINGHAM-SHIRE MEN DELIVERED THE XIth OF January, one to the PEERS, the other to the Hou≈øe of Commons, in the behalfe of Mr. Hampden, Burge≈ø≈øe for their Shire, &c. They being 4000. that came on Hor≈øeback to deliver them.

And al≈øo a Relation of the free and voluntary offers of the Trayned Bands of the City of London; of the Ma≈øters of Shippes, Mariners and Seamen; of the Aprentices of London; of the Trayned Bands of Southwarke, and of the Watermen upon the Thames to defend the King and Parliament again≈øt malignant Councells and Plots of Papi≈øts.

div.head: A TRUE RELATION Of ≈øundry pa≈ø≈øages in and about the mo≈øt honourable Hou≈øe of PARLIAMENT.
div.p: ON Munday the third of this in≈øtant month of January, his Maje≈øty by Warrant under his own hand, Authorized Sergeant Frances, Sergeant at Armes, to come to the Hou≈øe of Commons, and there to demand Mr. Denzill Hollis, Sir Arthur Ha≈ølerigg, Mr. Pym, Mr. Hampden, and Mr. Strowd, whom in his Maje≈øties name, he accu≈øed of High Trea≈øon.

The Hou≈øe of Commons returned this an≈øwere, that not only tho≈øe five Gentlemen, but al≈øo every one of them would lay downe their lives and fortunes at his Maje≈øties feet, ≈øo he would be but plea≈øed to accu≈øe them in a legall way, and make known the cau≈øe of their Accu≈øation.

The next day being Tue≈øday, his Maje≈øty (unexpectedly) came to the Hou≈øe of Commons attended with a multitude of per≈øons Armed as afore≈øaid, and there in the SPEAKERS Chaire, demanded the≈øe five Per≈øons, ≈øaying he expected ye≈øterday obedience,
and not an An≈øwere: When his Maje≈øty a long time together had ca≈øt his eyes round about the Hou≈øe, and could not di≈øcerne any of the≈øe five Members there, he was plea≈øed to command Mr. Speaker to tell him if they were there, the Speaker falling upon his knees humbly be≈øeeching his Maje≈øty to excu≈øe him, for he was ≈øervant to the Hou≈øe of Commons, and could neither ≈øee nor ≈øpeake without their leave.

His Maje≈øtie di≈øcerning they were not in the Hou≈øe, graciou≈øly departed; but the bloody minded ≈øouldiers, ≈øome of whom ≈øtood neere the doore of the Hou≈øe of Commons, with their Pi≈øtols readie cockt, and their Swords erected in their hands, expecting when the word ≈øhould have beene given with fearefull Oathes expre≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, that they lo≈øt that they came for, the per≈øons were not there, they mi≈øt the opportunity of cutting their throats, and the throats of all tho≈øe Parliament men of the Hou≈øe of Commons that would not have ≈øuffered the≈øe five per≈øons to have beene taken out of the Hou≈øe, his Maje≈øties owne ≈øervants carrying them≈øelves civilly, and indeed ignorant of the Trayterous de≈øigne.

As ≈øoone as the≈øe damme blades about the number of 400. were gone, the Hou≈øe of Commons, full of griefe of heart to ≈øee the priviledges of Parliament thus broken, adjourned in great di≈øcontent til Wedne≈øday, the 5. of Januarie, at two of the clock, at which time they met, and concluded of an Order to adjourne the Hou≈øe till Tu≈øeday, the 11. of January, 1641. And in the meane time, appointed a Comittee of the Hou≈øe of Commons to ≈øit in London,
to con≈øider of the ≈øafety of the King, Kingdome and Parliament, and of repairing of the priviledges of Parliament ≈øo highly broken.
Which meeting hath produced ≈øeverall Orders and Declarations for maintaining the priviledges of Parliament, which are to be reported to the Hou≈øe, and there to have it's force.

But for the ≈øafety of the Kingdome and Citie, which they conceived to be in emminent danger; the Committee for Iri≈øh affaires of the Hou≈øe of Commons propounded the con≈øideration thereof to the Committee of the Lords Hou≈øe for Iri≈øh affaires, who ≈øate likewi≈øe in London, who in regard the King had denyed both hou≈øes a Guard to protect them; and in regard ≈øuch an ho≈øtill plot was intended, as was apparantly proved declared their opinion, that whereas the King and Parliament was in ≈øo great danger; that in that ca≈øe the Sheriffes of London and Midle≈øex, ought to come with the Po≈ø≈øe Commitatus, to the Parliament to defend the King and Parliament, to which opinion the Comittee of the Hou≈øe of Commons a≈ø≈øented, which was communicated to the Lord Major, Aldermen and Common Coun≈øell of London, and they delivered their opinions herein, and expre≈ø≈øed their forwardne≈ø≈øe hereunto.

This breach of priviledge of Parliament begot much di≈øcontent in the Parliament and people, and the more in regard by ≈øpeciall command, the Articles again≈øt Ma≈øter Pym, and the re≈øt was printed, and the ≈øame publi≈øhed by Sir William Killegrue and Sir William Flemyn, and delivered in his Maje≈øties Name (as they fa≈øely pretended) to the foure Innes
of Court, to the end to make the≈øe per≈øons the more odious to them and the Kingdome: And in regard the con≈øequence of admitting this Accu≈øation in this manner again≈øt the≈øe five per≈øons, is a pre≈øident to take away the whole Hou≈øe of Commons at a breath, under pretence of high Trea≈øon, if (as God forbid) an Accun≈øation of this nature ≈øhould be hereafter; and con≈øidering that to this very day, (11. Januar. 1641.) no Articles of Impeachment is come into the Hou≈øe of Commons by the Kings Attourney or otherwi≈øe, or from the Lords Hou≈øe (if any be there again≈øt them) till which time that it come from thence by me≈ø≈øengers of their owne (if their fir≈øt depending) the Hou≈øe cannot legally take notice thereof: This, and many other rea≈øons, made the Hou≈øe of Commons to in≈øi≈øt upon it, be≈øides the great merit of the≈øe per≈øons, whom (as the hou≈øe hath declared) though as deare as their lives unto them, they will deliver over unto a tryall, ≈øo as his Maje≈øtie will proceed again≈øt them in a legall way, either at the Kings Bench, or in Parliament, and produce any Subject in England that will ≈øtand to make good the Accu≈øation, and in ca≈øe they faile to make it good, that his Majectie will let them be forth-comming, and al≈øo to di≈øcover tho≈øe wicked Coun≈øells that have advi≈øed him to this cour≈øe, that they may be brought to condigne puni≈øhment.

The City ond people in the adjacent parts are ≈øo much moved in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and fearing ≈øome ≈øuddaine execution may be done upon the Parliament (both the Hou≈øe of Peeres, and Hou≈øe of Commons, and the Lords of the Privy Coun≈øell, having declared
that this Act of his Maje≈øties without their advice, and again≈øt the privilledges of Parliament) That they ye≈øterday declared, that eight Companies of the Trayned Bands, with 8. pieces of Ordnance, and divers Hor≈øemen mounted, ≈øhall Guard the Commitees of the Hou≈øe of Peeres, and Commons, from Grocers-hall in London to We≈øtmin≈øter, And the Sea Captaines, Ma≈øters of Ships, and Marriners, with ≈ømall Barges, and long Boates ≈øufficiently man'd and Armed with Murderers, Rablets, Faulchion and Minion, with Mu≈øquets and halfe-Pikes, to the number of 2000 per≈øons have engaged them≈øelves to Guard the Parliament by water. The Trayned Bands in Southwark have offered them≈øelves to ≈øecure all the other ≈øide of the water, and the Aprentices tendred their ≈øervices to attend the Parliament to the number of ten thou≈øand with Warlike weapons, but tho≈øe the Parliament enjoyned to ≈øtay at home. And la≈øtly, the Watermen tendred their Barges for more ≈øafety to carry the Parliament men by Water: All which to the great admiration of all the Beholders, put in execution this day: And that which is mo≈øt con≈øiderable, 4000 Hor≈øemen are come to the hou≈øe of CoÃÑmons this day, except ≈øome of them which lay at Vxbridg and places thereabouts, with a Petition in the name of the whole County of Buckingham, that Mr. Hampden their Knight of the Shire may receive his Tryall, and not lie under the name of high Trea≈øon, and cannot obtaine a legall way of Tryall, and that if he acquit him≈øelfe (as no good men make doubt of) Ju≈øtice in a high mea≈øure may be done upon the fal≈øe informers of his Maje≈øty, how neere or how
a great ≈øoever; They being confident that it is but de≈øigne of the Popi≈øh party, to put an interruption in the proceedings of Parliament, that no reliefe may be ≈øent to Ireland, but that more Prote≈øtant blood may be ≈øhed there, and that all Acts made this Parliament, may be avoyded under pretence of no free Parliament: And la≈øtly to force a breach of this Parliament, by an untimely adjournment, or fayle of meeting through fear of danger.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Hou≈øe of PEEERS now a≈ø≈øembled in PARLIAMENT.
The Humble Petition of the Inhabitants of the County of Buckingham.
div.p: THAT whereas we hoped upon the happy a≈ø≈øembly of this pre≈øent Parliament, wee ≈øhould have had a ≈øpeedy redre≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe great pre≈ø≈øures, we had for many yeares been under, but have hitherto been in great mea≈øure fru≈øtrate of our hopes by the ≈øtrange Counter-working of a malignant faction, whereby the perfecting of Reformation is hindred, the endeavours of the Hou≈øe of Commons, in great part ≈øucce≈ø≈øele≈ø≈øe, our dangers growne upon us by iterated plots, Prie≈øts and other Delinquents unpuni≈øhed, to the encouragement of others, Ireland neare lo≈øt by protracted Coun≈øels, while Thou≈øands are there Butchered by inhume cruelties; and to cut off all hopes of future Reformation, the very being of our Parliaments indangered by de≈øperate and unexampled breach of privilledges; which by our Prote≈øtation lately taken we are bound with our lives and e≈øtates to maintaine. And in re≈øpect of that late attempt upon the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons, we are now come to offer our ≈øervice to that end; as re≈øolved in their ju≈øt defence to live and die.

ANd do therfore humbly pray that this mo≈øt Honourable Hou≈øe will cooperate with the Hou≈øe of Commons in mo≈øt
≈øpeedy perfecting the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary worke of Reformation, bringing to condidge and exemplary puni≈øhment both wicked Coun≈øellors and other plotters and delinquents. That Ireland may be ≈øpeedily relieved, the Priviledges of Parliament fortified again≈øt all future attempts. And the whole Kingdome put into ≈øuch o pre≈øent po≈øture of defence, that wee may be ≈øafe both from all pra & ices of the malignant party at home, and the endeovours of any ill affected States abroad.

div.head: To the Honourable the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes, of the Hou≈øe of Commons, now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament
div.p: THat whereas for many yeares pa≈øt we have beene under very great pre≈ø≈øures (which are cleerly ≈øet forth in the late Remon≈øtrance of the Hou≈øe of Commons: The reder≈ø≈øe thereof which hath for a long time beene by you indeavoured with unwearied paines though not with an≈øwerable ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, having ≈øtill your endeavour, fru≈øtrated or retarded, and we deprived of the fruit thereof by a malignant faction of Popi≈øh Lords, Bi≈øhops, and others and now of late, to take from us all that little hope was left of a future reformation: the very being of the Parliament ≈øhaken, and by the mi≈øchievous practi≈øes of mo≈øt wicked Coun≈øellors the Priviledges therof broken in an unexampled manner and the members therof una≈ø≈øured of their lives, in who≈øe ≈øafety the ≈øafety of us and our Po≈øterity is involved. Wee held it our duty according to our late Prote≈øtation to defend and maintaine the ≈øame Per≈øons and Priviledges, to the utmo≈øt expence of our Lives and E≈øtates. To which purpo≈øe we are now come to make the humble tender of our ≈øervice, and remaine in exepctation of your Command and Order; to the execution whereof, we ≈øhall with all alacrity addre≈ø≈øe our ≈øelves, ready to live by you, or to die at your feet, again≈øt whom≈øoever ≈øhall in any ≈øort illegally attempt upon you.

MAy it therefore plea≈øe this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ardent Prayer of your poore Petitioners, that Popi≈øh Lords and Bi≈øhops may be forthwith outed the Hou≈øe of Peeres, that all Priviledges of Parliament (Yours and our Po≈øterities Inheritance) may bee confirmed to you, and that evill Coun≈øellors, the Achans of this Commonwealth, may be given up to the hand of Ju≈øtice; without all which your Petitioners have not the lea≈øt hope of I≈øraels peace, or to reape tho≈øe glorious advantages, which the 14. Months ≈øeed-time of your unparalleld endeavours hath given to their un≈øatisfied expectations.
